name: The Rollbar alert lamp
tagline: A 3D printed lamp that changes its behavior upon receiving a rollbar alert
body:
### General Description of the lamp

This 3D printed desktop lamp is enabled by a [Particle Photon](https://www.particle.io/). The Photon is a prototyping tool that comes with a Wi-Fi chipset. This enables interfacing sensors/actuators to the internet and monitor them remotely. This lamp is equipped with a 24 Pixel circular RGB LED strip called the [Neopixel from Adafruit Industries ](https://www.adafruit.com/product/1586). 

The Particle Photon can produce different color combinations on the RGB LED strip as shown in the picture below:  
  

![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/sai-y/photon_desktop_lamp/master/desktop_lamp.jpg) 

## Building the lamp

The following are needed to build the lamp:  
  
1. [Particle Photon](https://store.particle.io/)  
2. 3D printed enclosure + lamp shade  
3. Micro USB cable  
4. [24 pixel Neopixel ring](https://www.adafruit.com/products/2268). 
  
## Particle Photon - Firmware + Setup

The Particle Photon has to be setup to receive rollbar alerts. This includes adding the [WiFi credentials](https://docs.particle.io/guide/getting-started/start/photon/) to the Photon. 
The firmware files for Particle Photon is available from [here](https://github.com/sai-y/photon_desktop_lamp/tree/master/firmware). This [tutorial](https://docs.particle.io/guide/getting-started/build/photon/) explains compiling the code and flashing it on the Photon.  
  
The firmware consists of two major components:   

1. Controlling the neopixel  
2. Receiving incoming alerts from the web.  
  
### Controlling the neopixel:
There are libraries from Adafruit to control the neopixel using the Particle Photon. This firmware used to build this lamp was based on one of the examples available with the library.  
  
### Receiving incoming alerts from the web:  
The Particle Photon enables registering a function that could be executed when a rollbar alert is received. For e.g.: A function called `triggerAlert`can be registered as follows:  
  
`    bool success = Particle.function("trigger", triggerAlert);`  
  
The string `trigger` is used to make a POST request to the Particle API. The function `triggerAlert` is used to set a flag that is used to control the behavior of the lamp: 
  

     // this is the function that is called when a trigger is received 
     int triggerAlert(String command){
        if(command == "triggered"){
            if(true){
                triggerReceived = true;
                return 1;
            }
        }
        return -1;
    }


  


When there are no rollbar alerts, the lamp glows white:  

![](http://i.imgur.com/2F0I7H2.gif)
  
In order to trigger the Particle Photon for an alert, the device id and an access token is necessary. This information is available at [particle.io](https://docs.particle.io/guide/getting-started/intro/photon/)

![](http://i.imgur.com/fc4jrqk.jpg) ![](http://i.imgur.com/xgCMGtR.jpg)

## Setting up Rollbar webhooks

The alert could be sent to a Particle Photon using Rollbar's webhook notification option. 
![](http://i.imgur.com/fMsafqZ.jpg)
